question: The infratrochlear nerve is a branch of which larger nerve?
short_explanation: The infratrochlear nerve branches from the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V1).
long_explanation: Specifically, the infratrochlear nerve arises from the nasociliary branch of the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve, providing sensory innervation to parts of the medial orbit and nose.
applied_example: A massage therapist applying pressure near the medial orbit must be cautious of the infratrochlear nerve to avoid discomfort.
text: The infratrochlear nerve is a branch of which larger nerve?

question: Which area is primarily innervated by the infratrochlear nerve?
answers: Medial upper eyelid and side of the nose
short_explanation: It supplies the medial upper eyelid, conjunctiva, and side of the nose.
long_explanation: The infratrochlear nerve provides cutaneous sensory innervation to the skin of the medial upper eyelid, the lacrimal sac, conjunctiva, and the bridge of the nose.
applied_example: Pressure during facial massage near the medial canthus may stimulate the infratrochlear nerve, affecting comfort.
text: Which area is primarily innervated by the infratrochlear nerve?
options: Medial upper eyelid and side of the nose
correctAnswer: Medial upper eyelid and side of the nose
abcd: C. Medial upper eyelid and side of the nose

question: The infratrochlear nerve passes beneath which structure to reach its target area?
short_explanation: It runs beneath the trochlea of the superior oblique muscle.
long_explanation: The nerve is named for its course under the trochlea, a cartilaginous pulley-like structure for the superior oblique muscle, before reaching the anterior orbit.
applied_example: Knowledge of its path is useful in surgical or therapeutic procedures involving the medial orbit.
text: The infratrochlear nerve passes beneath which structure to reach its target area?
abcd: A. Trochlea of the superior oblique

question: Which sensory function does the infratrochlear nerve NOT perform?
short_explanation: It does not provide motor innervation to muscles.
long_explanation: The infratrochlear nerve is purely sensory; motor innervation to eye muscles is handled by CN III, IV, and VI.
applied_example: Loss of sensation without motor impairment points to sensory nerves like the infratrochlear rather than motor cranial nerves.
text: Which sensory function does the infratrochlear nerve NOT perform?
abcd: A. Skin of the medial eyelid
D. Muscle control of the eye

question: Infratrochlear nerve branches from which nasociliary subdivision?
short_explanation: It is the terminal branch of the nasociliary nerve.
long_explanation: The infratrochlear nerve is the final branch of the nasociliary nerve, itself a branch of the ophthalmic nerve (CN V1).
applied_example: Disruption to nasociliary branches may affect multiple sensory zones in the orbit and nasal root.
text: Infratrochlear nerve branches from which nasociliary subdivision?
abcd: D. Terminal branch of nasociliary nerve

question: Which of the following may cause infratrochlear nerve irritation?
short_explanation: Proximity to the ethmoidal sinus makes it susceptible to sinus inflammation.
long_explanation: Since the infratrochlear nerve is near the ethmoidal air cells, inflammation or infection can cause irritation and sensory disturbance.
applied_example: Clients with frontal sinus pressure and orbital discomfort may be experiencing referred symptoms affecting the infratrochlear nerve.
text: Which of the following may cause infratrochlear nerve irritation?

question: Which massage technique might stimulate the infratrochlear nerve?
answers: Gentle circular pressure at the medial orbital rim
short_explanation: The nerve lies beneath the trochlea near the medial orbital margin.
long_explanation: Pressure in this region can stimulate the infratrochlear nerve or elicit sensations due to its superficial path.
applied_example: Practitioners should use caution when working around the medial eye region to avoid nerve irritation.
text: Which massage technique might stimulate the infratrochlear nerve?
options: Gentle circular pressure at the medial orbital rim
correctAnswer: Gentle circular pressure at the medial orbital rim
abcd: B. Effleurage over the lateral jaw
C. Gentle circular pressure at the medial orbital rim

question: Damage to the infratrochlear nerve may affect which reflex?
short_explanation: It contributes to the afferent limb of the corneal reflex.
long_explanation: The sensory limb of the corneal reflex involves CN V1 (via nasociliary/infratrochlear), while the motor limb is CN VII. Disruption may diminish blinking to touch.
applied_example: Testing the corneal reflex is used in assessing cranial nerve V1 sensory integrity in head trauma.
text: Damage to the infratrochlear nerve may affect which reflex?

question: The infratrochlear nerve contributes to innervation of which lacrimal structure?
short_explanation: It provides sensation to the lacrimal sac area.
long_explanation: Though it does not control lacrimation, the infratrochlear nerve supplies sensory innervation to the overlying skin and lacrimal sac region.
applied_example: Clients with inflammation near the lacrimal sac may report sensory symptoms due to infratrochlear nerve involvement.
text: The infratrochlear nerve contributes to innervation of which lacrimal structure?

question: Which of the following is a distinguishing feature of the infratrochlear nerve?
answers: It enters the skull via foramen ovale
It lies medial to the trochlea
It exits through the infraorbital foramen
short_explanation: Its name refers to its position just medial and beneath the trochlea.
long_explanation: The infratrochlear nerve lies near the medial orbital wall under the trochlea. It exits via the superior orbital fissure as part of CN V1 distribution.
applied_example: Palpation around this region should be done gently during therapeutic sessions involving the face.
text: Which of the following is a distinguishing feature of the infratrochlear nerve?
options: It enters the skull via foramen ovale
It lies medial to the trochlea
It exits through the infraorbital foramen
correctAnswer: It lies medial to the trochlea
abcd: B. It enters the skull via foramen ovale
C. It lies medial to the trochlea
D. It exits through the infraorbital foramen
